question.body: What are the issues which affect the decision between setting up a wired network or a wireless network?

answer.body: Cost, Ease of Deployment, Scalability, and Flexibility.

question.body: What are some advantages of wireless networks?

answer.body: Mobility, Ease of deployment, Reduced Cost-of-Ownership, Scalability, and Flexibility.

question.body: What are some disadvantages of wireless networks?

answer.body: Setup and Configuration, Stability, Security, and Speed.

question.body: List and discuss 3 aspects/areas of personal mobile communication impacted by mobility.

answer.body: Mobile Devices: Lighter, more robust, constrained by battery; Network Protocols: Change in name, address, location, etc.; Security: Endpoint authentication is harder; Performance: Network is slower and delay and jitter are increased; Operation: Need software resources to track and manage devices; Applications: Need to deal with changes in connectivity and QoS;

question.body: What is the Hidden Node Problem and how is it solved?

answer.body: When two nodes that are invisible to each other communicate with a third node, their transmissions interfere, as they can not sense the carrier. Handshaking using RTS/CTS (Request to Send/Clear to Send) is implemented in conjunction with the CSMA/CA to overcome this problem.

question.body: What is the Exposed Node Problem and how is it solved?

answer.body: When a node is transmitting to another node and a third node wants to transmit to a fourth one, the third node may falsely believe that it can not do so because it would cause interference. In reality the second node might be outside of transmission range of node three and the fourth node out of transmission range of node one. RTS/CTS messages may be used to overcome this problem under certain circumstances.

question.body: List 3 impairments to wireless signal propagation and explain how each impairment can be alleviated.

answer.body: Attenuation and Attenuation Distortion: Adaptive equalizer; Free Space Loss: Boost signal strength; Multipath Propagation: Forward error correction;

question.body: List 3 common sources of noise in wireless communication systems and explain their causes.

answer.body: Thermal noise: Function of temperature; Intermodulation noise: Occurs if signals with different frequencies share the same medium; Crosstalk: One circuit accidentally picks up signals in another

question.body: What are the 2 common algorithms used in an adaptive filter to derive the optimum weights of the filter? State the cost functions used by the 2 algorithms to minimize the error signal.

answer.body: Least Mean Squares (LMS) and Recursive Least Square (RLS).

question.body: What are the 3 common important signal propagation mechanisms that result in multipath propagation of wireless signals?

answer.body: Reflection, Diffraction, and Scattering.

question.body: What are the characteristics of a Rayleigh fading channel?

answer.body: Large number of multipath signals with no dominant signal along line-of-sight.

question.body: What are the characteristics of a Rician fading channel?

answer.body: Large number of multipath signals with a dominant signal.

question.body: What are the 2 basic properties that determine the quality of digitized speech signal?

answer.body: Sampling rate and bit depth.

question.body: List and briefly explain the 3 basic types of digital modulation.

answer.body: Amplitude (ASK), Frequency (FSK), Phase (PSK) Shift Keying

question.body: What are the 2 transmission techniques used?

answer.body: Narrow‐band transmission: Each signal transmits on one radio frequency, or a very narrow range of frequencies; Spread spectrum transmission: Transmitter takes a narrow band signal and spreads it over a broader portion of the radio frequency band

question.body: What are the 2 common spread spectrum techniques used? Briefly explain their operations.

answer.body: Frequency Hopping Spread Spectrum (FHSS): Use a range of frequencies and change frequency multiple times during transmission; Direct Sequence Spread Spectrum (DSSS): Uses an expanded redundant code to encode each data bit before transmitting

question.body: What are the 3 most common techniques adopted to support multiple access in wireless communication?

answer.body: Frequency Division Multiple Access (FDMA), Time Division Multiple Access (TDMA), and Code Division Multiple Access (CDMA)

question.body: FDMA is susceptible to crosstalk. Suggest a common mechanism to reduce crosstalk. What is the disadvantage of using this mechanism.

answer.body: Special guard band frequencies are used to prevent the frequencies from “bleeding” over one another. This reduces usable bandwidth.

question.body: How many active master device(s) and active slave device(s) can be supported in a Bluetooth piconet?

answer.body: 1 active master and 7 active slaves.

question.body: Bluetooth slave devices can communicate with one another directly. Is this statement true or false?

answer.body: False. Slave devices can only communicate with the master.

question.body: How does Bluetooth enable all devices in a Piconet to communicate without interference and to allow them to share the channel?

answer.body: It uses FHSS to allow devices to communicate without interference and TDD-TDMA to share the channel.

question.body: Explain how a Bluetooth device performs the discovery of the other Bluetooth devices within its range.

answer.body: Inquiry and Page from the Inquiring Device, Inquiry and Page Scan from the other devices

question.body: With FHSS, explain how the Bluetooth discovery process ensure that the receiver can be discovered since they may be using different frequency channels?

answer.body: Inquiring device inquires using many channels and receivers can issue multiple inquiry responses.

question.body: Explain why the Bluetooth discovery process can take as long as 10.24s.

answer.body: Full scan of 32 frequencies (with 128 repetitions) is repeated up to 4 times: 4 * 2,56s.

question.body: Explain the difference in the operation of a Bluetooth slave device being assigned a 3‐bit Active Member Address (AMA) versus one being assigned an 8‐bit Passive Member Address (PMA)!

answer.body: Active devices (with AMA) can send and receive data. Parked devices release the AMA and are assigned a PMA. They cannot send data but can listen on a beacon interval.

question.body: What is the AMA of the Bluetooth Master? What address is used by the Bluetooth Master to send a broadcast message?

answer.body: Both are 0.

question.body: List and explain the 3 power saving modes for Bluetooth devices!

answer.body: Hold: Master and slave agree on a one‐time HOLD duration after which the slave synchronizes with the channel traffic and data transfer restarts. Slave keeps AMA.; Sniff: Slave listens at a reduced rate and keeps AMA.; Park: Slave looses AMA, gets PMA, and can not send any more.

question.body: What is the purpose of Bluetooth pairing?

answer.body: Pairing using PIN is a security mechanism to restrict access to authorised users only.

question.body: Explain the digital modulation used by Bluetooth!

answer.body: GFSK has a carrier frequency, called the center frequency (fc) and it uses 2 different frequencies to indicate a 1 (higher) or a 0 (lower) being tx.

question.body: List and explain the 2 types of links that can be created between the Bluetooth master and slave!

answer.body: Syn Connection Oriented (SCO): faster, for real‐time data, max 3 links to 1 master; Asyn Connection‐Less (ACL): slower, best effort transfer, max 1 link to 1 master

question.body: What are some of the differences between Standard Bluetooth and Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE)?

answer.body: BLE uses Adaptive Frequency Hopping (AFH) and has no limit on the number of slaves. It also features very low-power sleep modes. (AND MORE)

question.body: What are two factors that affect the throughput of a user in a WLAN?

answer.body: Distance from AP; Number of users sharing the aggregate bandwidth of the AP

question.body: What are the two general modes for WLAN?

answer.body: Infrastructure mode and Ad-hoc mode

question.body: What are characteristics of WLAN in infrastructure mode?

answer.body: Stations communicate with AP only; AP requires strategic placement; AP connects to wired backbone network

question.body: What are characteristics of WLAN in ad-hoc mode?

answer.body: No fixed connection; Nodes transmit directly to each other; Poor performance as users are spread out

question.body: List and briefly explain the services provided by a WLAN stationt!

answer.body: Authetication: proves identity of one station to another; Deauthentication: removes previously authenticated station; Privacy: prevents messages from being read by unintended recipient; Data Delivery: provides reliable delivery from MAC of one station to MAC of other stations

question.body: List and briefly explain the services provided by a WLAN Access Point!

answer.body: Association: makes logical connection between stations and AP; Disassociation: used to inform AP that station is no longer requiring service; Reassociation: used when station moves to new BSS (new AP); Distribution: determines where to send packets; Integration: allows connection to other wired and wireless LANs

question.body: List any three general types of Media Access Control!

answer.body: TDMA, FDMA, FHSS, DSSS, CDMA, SDMA, and Random Access

question.body: List the two coordination functions used for media access in WLAN and list two characteristics for each function.

answer.body: DCF (Distributed Coordination Function): For infrastructure and ad-hoc mode, uses CSMA/CA+ACK and contention resolution; PCF(Point Coordination Function): For infrastructure mode only, the AP has to allow a station to send

question.body: What is Inter Frame Spacing (IFS) and what is its purpose?

answer.body: Refers to time interval between two successive frames by any station. Used to reduce collision probability and prioritize different packets.

question.body: List and explain the 4 IFS used in the basic 802.11 WLAN operation!

answer.body: SIFS (Short IFS): Used for immediate response actions (e.g. ACK); PIFS (Point coordination function IFS): Used by centralized controller in PCF scheme; DIFS (Distributed coordination function IFS): Used as minimum delay of asynchronous frames contending for access; EIFS (Extended IFS): Used for resynchronization when PHY detects incorrect MAC frame reception

question.body: List 3 control access techniques in DCF and explain the scenario in which the control access technique is most applicable!

answer.body: CSMA/CA+ACK: Error-free channel; RTS/CTS: presence of hidden terminal/ interference; Fragmentation: high number of retransmissions

question.body: What is the function of the Network Allocation Vector (NAV) in 802.11?

answer.body: It is used for the implementation of virtual carrier sense that works by specifying the duration of a transmission in the frame header. Stations can copy the duration value into their NAV and count down until the medium is not busy any more. It also helps conserving power by reducing the need for physical carrier sensing.

question.body: Explain what happens when the Contention Period in one superframe (i.e. contention-free repetition period) overruns into the next superframe!

answer.body: The CFP is foreshortened.

question.body: Briefly explain how OFDM and MIMO operate!

answer.body: Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing: Divides the wide channel into many subchannels (called subcarriers), Sends part of the message frame in each subcarrier in parallel, Subcarrier tx are redundant; Multiple Input/Multiple Output: Two or more spatial streams can be sent at the same time in the same channel but from different sending antennas, Reveiver uses multipath time differences to distinguish between them

question.body: What are the advantages of OFDM and MIMO?

answer.body: OFDM: Very easy and efficient in dealing with multi‐path, Robust against narrow‐band interference; MIMO: Increases throughput, Robust against multipath fading

question.body: List and briefly explain the techniques used in 802.11n to improve throughput.

answer.body: MIMO: up to 4 spatial streams; Channel Bonding: use two separate channels at once; Frame Aggregation: combine small frames to decrease protocol overhead; Utilization of dual‐radio RF band: one radio for 2,5GHz and 5GHz region each

question.body: List and briefly explain the techniques used in 802.11ac to improve throughput.

answer.body: Beamforming with MIMO: up to 8 spatial streams that are directed towards the target; Channel Bonding: use two separate channels at once; MU-MIMO (Multi-User MIMO): AP can transmit multiple frames to different clients simultaneously on the same frequency spectrum; Denser Modulation: 256 QAM

question.body: What are the 2 coordination functions used in 802.11e?

answer.body: EDCF (Enhanced DCF): Station with higher priority traffic waits less to transmit, Used in CP only; HCF (Hybrid coordination function): Combination of DCF and PCF, Uses ECDF in CP, AP controls access in CFP and allocates more timeslots to stations with high-priority traffic

question.body: How does HCF gain access to the channel during the Contention Period?

answer.body: HC can allocate polled TXOPs (Transmit Opportunity) by issuing QoS CF-Poll after detecting the channel as being idle for PIFS, which is shorter than DIFS. Hence HC has priority.

question.body: List 2 characteristics each for Circuit Switching, Packet Switching and Message Switching technologies.
Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of circuit switching technology and packet switching technology.

answer.body: Circuit switching provides low delays, but needs a setup phase and blocks resources during the entire connection time, even if no data is sent. Packet switching provides better line efficiency and is more reliable, but may have higher delays and has jitter.

question.body: Name and explain the 3 common cellular phone codes used.
What is the main design characteristic of cellular networks which allow them to offer high capacity in a limited frequency spectrum?

answer.body: Frequency reuse.

question.body: Explain how the cellular phone system is able to support frequency reuse.

answer.body: BS and cell phones operate at low power. Adjacent cells are assigned different frequencies. Frequencies are reused every few cells.

question.body: Explain why a cluster size of 1 is not recommended in a cellular system using FDMA.

answer.body: Too much interference.

question.body: Explain why IS-95 cellular system using CDMA/DSSS can have a frequency reuse factor of 1.

answer.body: CDMA allows multiple transmissions on the same frequency.

question.body: Explain the difference between handoff and roaming in the context of a cellular phone network.

answer.body: Handoff means a user is switching cells within a network. Roaming means a user is switching between networks.

question.body: Explain the difference between hard and soft handoffs.

answer.body: Hard handoff means cutting communications with one BS before connecting to the new BS, while soft handoff is the opposite.

question.body: Explain why handoff margin cannot be too large or too small.

answer.body: If it is too large it will cause unnecessary handoffs and if it is too small calls will be lost before the handoff is complete.

question.body: Explain how a call is received on a cell phone.

answer.body: The phone registers with cell it has the strongest signal to. This registration is forwarded to the MTSO as well. When a call comes in the MTSO finds the called phone by registration and sets a frequency pair for phone and BS to use. Once the phone accepted the call the MTSO sets up a circuit between calling and called BS as well as traffic channels within the caller and called BS.

question.body: AMPS uses FDMA to divide a 25 MHz band into 30 kHz channels. However, only 832 channels are defined as available for use. Explain the use of the 833rd channel.

answer.body: It is used as a guard band.

question.body: Explain the 2 key factors which allows the 2G and above cellular technologies to increase system capacity over 1G cellular technologies.

answer.body: Efficient use of frequency spectrum and less transmitter power.

question.body: In GSM, a 25 MHz band is divided into 124 200 kHz physical channels using FDMA. What and where is the 125th channel used for.

answer.body: The last channel is split into two 100 kHz channels. They are guard bands at the beginning and end of the 124 carrier channels.

question.body: List 3 advantages of CDMA based cellular phone systems.

answer.body: Frequency diversity: everyone is allocated the entire frequency spectrum which reduces frequency-dependant transmission impairments; Multipath resistance: chipping codes used for CDMA exhibit low cross correlation and low autocorrelation; Privacy: since signals are noise-like and encoded

question.body: What are the roles of the Master Ground station in the GPS system?

answer.body: The Master Ground station sends orbital data and clock corrections it receives from other ground stations to the satellites. The satellites can then incorporate these updates into the signals they send to GPS receivers.

question.body: What is the number of satellites needed to compute the location of a GPS user?
List and briefly explain the 3 sets of signals transmitted by the GPS space vehicles.
Explain how the measurements from the 4th satellite can be used by a GPS receiver to determine a correction factor to offset the drift in the receiver’s clock from the satellite clock.

answer.body: The receiver can look for a single correction factor for its timings that would lead to all 4 satellites measurements to have one single intersection. This correction brings the Receiver back in sync.

question.body: List and briefly explain 2 methods used for time measurements in GPS receivers.

answer.body: Carrier phase ranging: phase difference of a received carrier compared to a reference carrier can be used to compute time on arrival; Code phase ranging: phase difference of a received code compared to a reference code can be used to compute time on arrival

question.body: Which pilot signal(s) is/are used in Standard Positioning Services (SPS) and Precision Positioning Services (PPS)?

answer.body: SPS: code phase ranging using spread pilot signal on L1; PPS: code phase ranging using spread pilot signals on L1 and L2

question.body: List and briefly explain the sources of errors in GPS positioning system.

answer.body: Ionospheric error: ionosphere slows signal propagation; Tropospheric error: troposphere slows signal propagation; Clock and ephemeris errors; Receiver noise; Multipath

question.body: Explain how satellite alignment affects the Dilution of Precision (DoP).

answer.body: GPS satellites close together lead to a large area of uncertainty when calculating an intersection and hence high DoP.

question.body: How does Differential GPS improve the accuracy of the location determined?

answer.body: A reference station constantly computes the difference between actual distance and measured distance to all visible satellites. From this difference it computes correction data for each satellite and directly broadcasts it to mobile receivers nearby.
